The 1960s saw a significant increase in Filipino migration to the United States, which was then the imperial metropole of the Philippines. There were several factors that contributed to this migration wave.

One of the main drivers of Filipino migration to the United States was economic. The Philippines was experiencing high levels of unemployment and poverty in the 1960s, and many Filipinos saw the United States as a land of opportunity where they could find better-paying jobs and improve their economic situation.

Another factor was the passage of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965, which abolished the quota system that had previously restricted immigration from non-European countries. This meant that more Filipinos were able to obtain visas to migrate to the United States.

In addition to economic and legal factors, there were also cultural and historical ties between the Philippines and the United States that facilitated migration. The Philippines had been a U.S. colony from 1898 until 1946, and many Filipinos had been exposed to American culture and language. This made it easier for Filipinos to adapt to life in the United States and to navigate the immigration process.

Filipino migration to the United States in the 1960s had a significant impact on both countries. In the United States, Filipino migrants played an important role in filling labor shortages in sectors such as healthcare and education. They also formed vibrant communities in cities such as Los Angeles and San Francisco, which helped to promote Filipino culture and identity.

In the Philippines, migration to the United States had both positive and negative effects. On the one hand, remittances from Filipino migrants helped to alleviate poverty and support economic development. On the other hand, the brain drain caused by emigration of highly skilled workers has been cited as a hindrance to the Philippines' economic development.
